derivation.yuyuan_name: late 15th cent. (originally used of sight, in the sense 'accurate, unerring'): from medieval Latin intuitivus, from Latin intueri (see intuit)

entry.def: If you have an intuitive idea or feeling about something, you feel that it is true although you have no evidence or proof of it.

example.ex: A positive pregnancy test soon confirmed her intuitive feelings.
example.tran: 阳性孕检结果很快证实了她的直觉。

means.word_mean: 1. spontaneously derived from or prompted by a natural tendency;
2. obtained through intuition rather than from reasoning or observation

auth_sentence.content: To find out she devised this cunning counter-intuitive apparatus.

Sentence.sentence: Kapur points out that while the model adopted by many teachers when introducing students to new knowledge―providing lots of structure and guidance early on, until the students show that they can do it on their own―makes intuitive sense, it may not be the best way to promote learning.

means.word_mean: 有直觉力的;凭直觉获知的

sentences.en: He seemed to have an intuitive knowledge of how I was feeling.
sentences.cn: 他好像凭直觉就知道我的感受。
